description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)

description: A general curfew will apply in Georgia from Tuesday (31 March) at 08:00 a.m. (local time). Persons are only allowed to leave their apartments for necessary purchases. In addition, there is an absolute night-time curfew between 09:00 p.m. and 06:00 a.m., which also applies countrywide. Public gatherings of more than three people and public transport are also to be suspended, with the exception of taxis.

description:
On June 2, 2020, ir was reported that Georgian international airports are preparing to receive international visitors starting July 1. TAV Georgia, the operator of Tbilisi and Batumi International Airports, has already ensured all the requirements for the safety of travelers at the Tbilisi International Airport, including setting up disinfectant machines for hands and thermal cameras to scan passengers arriving at the airports to detect whether they have a high temperature. UPDATE: On June 25, 2020, Georgian Civil Aviation Agency announced that international flights will not resume until August 1, 2020
Update: Originally, Georgia planned to resume international flights on July 1, 2020
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On August 17, Georgian aviation authorities previously announced that international flight restrictions have been extended until October 1. The Civil Aviation Agency further reported that the restrictions on regular international flights do not apply to direct international flights between Tbilisi International Airport (TBS) and the Airport of Munich (MUC), Paris- Charles de Gaulle (CDG), and Riga International Airport (RIX). UPDATE: On September 12, the Georgian Civil Aviation Agency has announced that coronavirus-related restrictions on regular international flights have been prolonged in Georgia until October 31. All international scheduled flights to/from Georgia are restricted. However, no restrictions apply to flights carried out between the airports of Tbilisi, Munich, Paris and Riga, as well as cargo, governmental, ambulance and emergency flights.

Update: Initially, restrictions were until October 1st

description:

have been allocated for treating coronavirus-infected patients
throughout the country. She said there is also space available for
additional 10,000 patients who do not need to be placed at
hospitals but rather be kept in quarantine.

description:
On April 9, 2020, The Ministry of Health of Georgia has expanded a list of novel coronavirus testing criteria, which will now also include organized groups and places of public assembly, like penitentiary and psychiatric facilities, elderly houses, defense forces, priests and monasteries. Initially, the COVID-19 testing algorithm included suspected patients with travel history in countries hit hard by the novel
coronavirus, people who had come into contact with patients
already diagnosed with the disease, as well as symptomatic
patients (with high fever), and high-risk groups such as frontline
medical personnel.

description:
On April 14 Prime Minister of Georgia has announced that the
government will shut down the countryʼs four largest cities – the
capital city of Tbilisi, Kutaisi, Batumi and Rustavi – for 10 days
effective from April 15, 21 00. Entering and leaving these cities will
be banned. On April 15 Prime Minister’s spokesperson Irakli Chikovani has announced at a news briefing  that, amid the closure of the country’s four largest cities – the capital city of Tbilisi, Kutaisi, Batumi and Rustavi, only registered residents will be allowed to enter those cities. Citizens registered elsewhere (in other municipalities) will be permitted to leave the said cities. He also introduced exceptions from the ban. description:
On April 13 The Georgian government has quarantined Khidiskuri village, part
of Khashuri municipality in Shida Kartli region (situated to the
northwest of Tbilisi), as two cases of COVID-19 have been
confirmed in the village. In addition to restrictions enacted by the
state of emergency decree, following regulations will come into
force in Khidiskuri:
entering and leaving the village will be banned;
Police force of the Ministry of Internal Affairs will ensure the
implementation and observance of quarantine restrictions;
Village residents can only leave their homes in case of
emergency;
Locals will be allowed to carry out farmwork in accordance
with the recommendations issued by the Ministry of Health;
Among the media outlets, only journalists of the Georgian
Public Broadcaster will be permitted to operate in the village. UPDATE: On April 28 the Government of Georgia Eases Strict Lockdown
Measures in Village in
Khashuri Municipality
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 23 the Government of Georgia has announced, that the supply and sale of all goods and products shall be suspended for the duration of the state of emergency. On April 2 added types of economic activities authorized under the state of emergency regulations which are effective until April 21. UPDATE: On April 2 the Georgian government has amended a decree issued on March 23 adding types of economic activities authorized under the state of emergency regulations which are effective until April 21. Oil and gas production companies, as well as businesses adopting remote work model will now be permitted to resume operations.

description: On April 15 State Representative of Imereti region in western Georgia stated that 13 cemeteries in Kutaisi and three cemeteries in Zestaponi municipality will be closed during the Easter celebrations. Shalamberidze could not yet specify the date of closure, but he said the cemeteries will be supposedly closed for three days to avoid large public gatherings amid the coronavirus.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the government service is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached

description:
On March 23 the Government of Georgia has announced, that Assemblies and/or demonstrations under the Law of Georgia on Assemblies and Demonstrations shall be prohibited for the
duration of the state of emergency.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On March 23, 2020, the Government of Georgia announced, that it shall be prohibited to hold all types of cultural events, both indoors and outdoors, including concerts, performances, temporary and permanent exhibitions, rehearsals, tours, master classes, trainings and conferences, with the exception of remote form.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 23, 2020, the Government of Georgia has announced that any assembly of more than 10 natural persons in a public space shall be prohibited. For the purposes of this article, a public space shall mean any indoor or outdoor area, unless it is a space used by individuals for residential purposes.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 23, 2020, the Government of Georgia announced, that all types of training, conferences, seminars, except for the remote form, shall be prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 28 State Representative of Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti region (Georgia) Alexandre Motserelia has announced about prohibiting travel of more than three people per car

description: Announced March 30, 2020: Georgia banned gatherings of more than three people, except for groceries and farmacies, where a distance of two meters is mandatory starting March 31.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Georgia, it is only allowed to travel in light vehicles (including taxis), taking into consideration the recommendations of the Ministry of Health, with a maximum of three people (including the driver), with the passengers seated in the back of the car, as of March 31st, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
